{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3677168,"name":"CC","username":"bddubs77","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/ad7895/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-09T13:22:48.572Z","cooked":"

Hi,

I’ve been trying to learn how to better characterize our robot for next year and started diving into SysID. While doing this, I realize I don’t really understand how Units work and I’m struggling to feed the correct parameter types into the Config method.

For example, the first parameter is of type Velocity. I can’t figure out how to specify that. I’ve blindly tried ofBaseUnits and ofRelativeUnits which are both accepted, but I honestly have no idea what those do and the docs aren’t to clear on these methods.

 new SysIdRoutine(
            new SysIdRoutine.Config(
                
       //*******  How do I Velocity<VoltageUnit>????       ********
        Velocity.ofBaseUnits(0.5, null), 

               Volts.of(2),

                null,         
                                     
                state -> SignalLogger.writeString("state", state.toString())
            )

I’d appreciate any help

A Velocity<VoltageUnit> means some number of volts per some unit time. So Volts.of(1).per(Seconds)

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-07-09T14:45:33.010Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":67,"readers_count":66,"score":43.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":504069,"topic_slug":"sysidroutine-config-unit-confusion","display_username":"Tim Winters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":56257,"username":"bddubs77","name":"CC","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/ad7895/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19820,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"78 AIR Strike Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/sysidroutine-config-unit-confusion/504069/3","custom_user_title":"78 AIR Strike Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":true,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3680893,"name":"CC","username":"bddubs77","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/ad7895/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-14T01:21:16.587Z","cooked":"

That makes so much sense, I have no idea how I would have figured that out. Is this a normal thing in Java? Could you point me towards a resource to read?

So

Velocity<VoltageUnit>
Volts.of(magnitude).per(Second)

Velocity<Distance>
Meters.of(magnitude).per(Second)
//etc.



//I would assume further that

Accleration<VoltageUnit>
Volts.of(magnitude).per(Second).per(Second)

//if volts/s^2 has some meaning in this context.

Thanks for helping!

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

The Java Units Library

The units library is a tool that helps programmers avoid mistakes related to units of measurement. It does this by keeping track of the units of measurement, and by ensuring that all operations are...

This should explain most of it
